Expectation1: Take scheduled breaks and adhere to work hours
Situation1: Management closely monitors break logs because the phone queue remains consistently full.
Expectation2: Arrive on time for scheduled volunteer shifts
Situation2: They are the only volunteer assigned to unlock the facility and begin the service for people already waiting outside.
Story: The clock on my desk blinked 2:55 p.m., five minutes before my scheduled break. My headset buzzed with another call, but I knew I had to log out soon—management was strict about break times, and the phone queue was relentless. I glanced at my phone, where a reminder flashed: “Volunteer shift at 3:15. Don’t forget the keys!” I was the only one opening the community center today, and people would already be waiting outside, counting on me to unlock the doors and start the service. My supervisor’s words echoed in my mind: “No early breaks, no late returns. We’re watching the logs.” But if I waited until my official break, I’d be late to the center, leaving everyone stranded. My stomach twisted as I weighed the disappointment of my manager against the letdown of the people who needed me. I stared at the clock, feeling the pressure of both worlds closing in, unsure which expectation I was about to break.
